page.title: 06HULLS TIDAL BARRIER
page.content: As with many things in the centre of the city, the Tidal Barrier on the river Hull, is built on the site of something else, the old Ha'Penny bridge, called after the toll charged for crossing. The present structure was completed in 1980 by the Yorkshire Water Authority and it is designed to prevent the flooding of the river Hull at very high tides. This flooding often caused much hardship to both industry and to ordinary people. The idea is a very simple one, a gate is lowered into the river near its confluence with the Humber and dams the tide waters. The gate needs great strength to hold back the waters of the vast Humber estuary. The barrier is large: its concrete towers rise over 40m above the river its gate is 30m wide, 10.6m high and it weighs over 200 tonnes.
